choices.C: SD-WAN route created for individual member interfaces
choices.B: Static route created with an Internet Services object
choices.D: SD-WAN rule created to route traffic based on link latency
choices.A: Static route created with a Named Address object

discussion.content:
B and D
In support of B - "Even though they are configured as static routes, ISDB routes are actually policy routes and take precedence over any other routes in the routing table. As such, ISDB routes are added to the policy routing table."
"Policy routes, and static routes created using ISDB addresses are not added to the routing table; they are added to the policy routing table."
In support of D - "Static routes are simple and are often used in small networks. Policy-based routes, however, are more flexible. They can match more than just the destination IP address. For example, if you have two links - a slow one and a fast one - you can route packets from low-priority source IPs to the slow link."
i think should be B&D
B,D is correct. Refer page 15 of Fortigate Infra study guide.
B & D are correct: As such, "ISDB routes" are added to the policy routing table. Similar to ISDB routes, "SD-WAN rules" function as policy routes.
I think taht it's C&D
B & D seems more accurate

Even though you must configure routes using the SD-WAN virtual interface, FortiGate installs individual routes for the member interfaces in the routing table. Information extracted from FortiGate_Infrastructure_6.2_Study_Guide-Online pag 72
Answer C,D

comments.content: This is talking about "policy route table"

discussion.content: C and D.
Correct answer is B & D

discussion.content: C is correct

discussion.content: The question is not valid- look at the drawing- port2 have connected subnet - 172.20.1.1/24 and it's not appearing in the routing table - which not making any sense. Also the answer is not correct because if you have connected subnet it's will always be preferred over static route- also - you can configure static route to subnet that is not same subnet of your port.
